title: Case Study 4
description:
Goal:
Boston Housing Data: Analyze and Model Housing Data using CART (Classification and Regression Trees) and Linear Regression. 
German Credit Data: Classify Credit Defaults Using Decision Trees
methodology:
Boston Housing Data: 
-Loaded data from the MASS library.
-Split into 90% training and 10% testing.
-Built and visualized a regression tree model predicting the target median home value (medv).
-Visualized the regression tree using the prp function.
-Calculated in-sample MSE (Mean Squared Error) at 17.2 and out-of-sample MSE at 27.4, indicating possible overfitting.
-Created a linear regression model, excluding ‘indus’ and ‘age’ variables.
-The linear regression model had in-sample MSE of 21.5 and out-of-sample MSE of 25.5, showing that CART might fit non-linear relationships better.
German Credit Data: 
-Loaded and preprocessed German Credit data, converting categorical variables into factors.
-Split the dataset into 80% training and 20% testing.
-Built a classification tree predicting credit defaults.
-Developed a second model applying a weighted cost matrix (false negatives cost 5x more than false positives).
-Compared the models and evaluated misclassification costs.
-Tested out-of-sample performance, showing possible improvements in handling misclassifications.

overview.story:
-Examined real-world housing and credit data to build predictive models.
-Compared different machine learning techniques to evaluate their effectiveness.
